reviewText:
Mega Coin Squad is a fast paced arcade-style platformer about collecting coins and hoarding them in your giant piggy bank.

The game features colorful high quality pixel art graphics in a style similar to Scott Pilgrim. The game boasts 5 characters, with unique stats, and 4 distinct worlds each containing 4 levels.

Multiplayer is local only.

Controls are tight, working with an XBox 360 pad right out of the box without issue. Movement feels good, just slightly floaty in a way that I personally enjoy and the jump is spot on with just enough Mario in it to seem familiar right out of the gate.

Each level asks the player to collect an ever increasing amount of coins and deliver them safely to the piggy bank. To aid in accomplishing this the player is given an arsenal of moves and weapons to over come obstacles and enemies including a multi-direction charge ability that clears enemies and blocks, assault rifles and rocket launchers to dispatch baddies and coin magnets and spawners to help you hit your goal and fill your bank.

I enjoyed this game immensely and recommend it on the strength of the graphics, music and single player experience alone.

Check out my first impression video below for more thoughts on Mega Coin Squad:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tkNlHthn6yk

reviewText: Adult Swim Games has an established track record of publishing quirky, off the wall indie games. These are often inspired by old 8-bit classics from past console generations and their newest release is no exception.  Mega Coin Squad is clearly inspired by Super Mario 3 and it makes no attempt at hiding this fact, emulating the look and feel of the NES classic while adding its own twist on the concept.\n\nMore: http://www.tech-gaming.com/mega-coin-squad-review/
voteText: 24 of 37 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Charge, hoard and destroy!


This polished 2D-Action-Platformer is ruthlessly easy to understand and frantic to play - especially with local friends.

Imagine the action-laden gameplay of your typical Mario-Game, spiced up by being able to charge in four directions. Now imagine being almost invulnerable while charging, as well as being able to destroy blocks. By now you should feel very mobile and with new exciting combat-options to explore.

This fun can be combined with up to three friends in four different, yet equally entertaining modes of competitive multiplayer.


While this game isn't heavy on content and extras by any means, it really struck me and my friends by its quality: the gameplay feels fresh, well balanced and highly dynamic, the presentation feels coherent and quite stylish, the menus are very easy and effective to navigate.

If you like your games to to be fun, direct, unique and with a little challenge, you should get this game.

reviewText: Mega Coin Squad is a 2D Platformer with a difference. Instead of getting from point A to Point B you're set free in an arena full of coins. Your aim is to collect them and fill up the Piggy Bank in the middle of the level. Sounds simple but MCS can be extremely challenging and thankfully never frustrating.\n\nMega Coin Squad will keep you coin collecting for hours and with a multiplayer that can rival big-guns like Fowerfall, this is a complete package from a fantastic developer. Can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
Thanks to Adult Swim Games and Big Pixel Studios for giving me the chance to play, and review this game early.

Lots of coin grabbing, platforming, blasting fun. Quite a challenging game, with a retro arcade style feel, and an awesome sound track.

There are 5 characters to choose from, each having their own strengths and weaknesses. You  get rewarded with diamonds each level in three ways:

(1) If you bank all your coins in one bankingi

(2) If you lose no lives(you get 3 each round)

(3) If you beat the clock.

I LPd this game live at www.twitch.tv/zombspawn, and the people in chat were really liking what they saw. Those people now want this game.

Of course, I am a noob, but I accept this challenging game, and will beat it. I plan on playing it through it's entirety in a future LP. My hand and eye coordination is not like it used to be, but having grown up on platformers, this is really an awesome one.

The intuitive controls are easy to master, and are best played with an Xbox 360 controller. I am not sure if other controller brands world, but I am guessing they will.

The overworld is similar to Mario games, where you travel from stage to stage.

My only wish is that there was an option for a certain ammount of continues. Losing in one round, can set you back to the begining round of that stage.

Nonetheless, I give this game a Mega Recommendtion, and encourage everyone to buy this game when it is released on August 15, 2014. :-)

I rate this game at a 4/5

reviewText:
Mega Coin Squad is an original and entertaining local multiplayer game with loads of replayability.

Each game is composed of several rounds of randomly chosen (or create your own playlist) game modes. In between each round you get character powerups based on your rank in the last game.

The game modes consist of a simple deathmatch, a mode where you have to collect and bank the most coins, hold the rainbow for a certain amount of time, or collect a set number of megacoins (that spawn one at a time) and bank them to win. These modes are all quite different and fun.

Mega Coin Squad is a very nice addition to any local multiplayer lineup.

Subscribe to my curator page for more local multiplayer recommendations: http://store.steampowered.com/curator/7189360/

Check out my Couch Gaming group for specials, bundles, etc: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/CGLM

reviewText:
I bought this game after watching the Quicklook on Giantbomb. My wife has always been funny about collecting all of the coins if we play a Mario game so I thought the way this game goes over the top with it would be enjoyable. The first world is pretty simple to do but the next ones are significantly more challenging. The game is definetely simple but I wouldn't call it easy!

We tried out the 4 player multiplayer last night and it worked really well, I don't see anything balance wise that needs to change. No problems with controller support, you can do everything in the game from a controller. The only thing you can't do with a controller is exit the game - you have to push the escape key on the PC, but that's not really a big deal.

The power-ups are of varying usefulness from what I can tell at this time. Invincibility is the only one that I think could use some work- it is not terribly obvious that you are invincible and I found it hard to tell when it was going to run out. The grenade launcher and 'drill cannon' shoot in an arc which can be annoying if you want to hit something directly in front of you - I have found myself avoiding using them. The machine gun, when upgraded, is the best power up in my opinion.

Also regarding upgrades, I have found that an upgraded fireball will go through solid walls which can be helpful when trying to kill enemies in the later stages.

In the end, I think this is a great game well worth the money. I know it is selling for $15 now, I think I bought it on the initial sale for $12 or something like that. The single player is enjoyable and is definetely challenging and the multiplayer works great. As I continue to play with friends I will update if I notice anything I think needs to change.

reviewText:
(Quick note, I was unable to play this game's multiplayer, so this review only applies to the single player content.)

http://youtu.be/CmH-CLvb0SY

Mega Coin Squad is a fast paced action arcade platformer in which you navigate around an ever changing level to grab enough coins to finish the level. The main purpose of the single player campaign is to try and get through the 4 worlds in as fast a time as possible. You can pick one of five characters to play through the game with, all of which have different stats, and track their game progress and game completion time separately.

Each world consists of 3 normal stages and 1 boss stage. In the normal stages you are given a coin quota to meet and will have to meet it without getting hit 3 times, lest you be sent back to the beginning of the world. Getting hit will cause you to drop all of your coins as well, but you can turn in the coins early to make sure you don't lose them. Each stage has it's own basic features and traps, but the main part of each stage is the constant generation of randomly selected, premade segments that contain coins, items, enemies and blocks. The game also encourages excelling at these stages, providing you with diamonds to spend on leveling up/unlocking abilities and items for beating it within a certain time, turning in all of your quota in one fell swoop, and never getting hit. The boss stages, however, are far less interesting. There are no diamonds to reward excellence or speed, don't get remotely difficult until world 4, and the fast and frantic search for coins is replaced with having to defeat a few waves of enemies. They almost feel out of place/tacked on.

Overall though, I can easily recommend this game to anybody who likes optimizing and improving times, completionists, or people who enjoy setting challenges for themselves (like no continues, or all diamonds). However, if you're the kind of guy who plays games solely to play it once and not touch it again, you might want to pass up on this game/wait for a sale, as you'll likely only get about 2-3 hours out of it.

A simple title with good pixel art and audio, but some odd performance problems that could be related just to my pc (any major action like getting hurt or picking up a weapn seemed to pause my game for a second or so).
